definitions.definition: to accept that something is true
definitions.sensetop: acknowledge somethingacknowledge that…acknowledge something to be, have, etc. something

examples.text: She refuses to acknowledge the need for reform.
I have to **acknowledge the fact** that I am partly responsible.
It's a generally acknowledged fact.
Most people acknowledge the existence of evil.
to openly/publicly/readily acknowledge something
He does not acknowledge that he has done anything wrong.
It is generally acknowledged to be true.
examples.contextForm: acknowledge something to be, have, etc. something

examples.text: A mental illness can exist for years before families are forced to acknowledge the truth.
a truth that is universally acknowledged
Are you prepared to acknowledge your responsibility?

definitions.definition: to accept that somebody/something has a particular authority or status
definitions.sensetop: acknowledge somebody/somethingbe acknowledged as somethingbe acknowledged to be, have, etc. something

examples.text: The country acknowledged his claim to the throne.
The peace settlement effectively acknowledged the country's independence.
He is **widely acknowledged **as the best player in the world.
He is **widely acknowledged **to be the best player in the world.
examples.contextForm: be acknowledged to be, have, etc. something

definitions.definition: to tell somebody that you have received something that they sent to you

examples.text: All applications will be acknowledged.
Please acknowledge receipt of this letter.
I hereby acknowledge receipt of your letter of 25 July.
The company duly acknowledged receipt of the letter.

definitions.definition: to show that you have noticed somebody/something by smiling, waving, etc.

examples.text: I was standing right next to her, but she didn't even acknowledge me.
He waved, acknowledging the applause.
They barely acknowledged each other.
He did not even acknowledge the question.

definitions.definition: to publicly express thanks for help you have been given

examples.text: I **gratefully acknowledge** financial support from several local businesses.
He is always ready to acknowledge his debt to his teachers.

wordOrigin: late 15th cent.: from the obsolete Middle English verb knowledge, influenced by obsolete acknow ‘acknowledge, confess’.
